head.title: Nassau County Buys Farm Development Rights

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: Nassau County Buys Farm Development Rights

abstract.p: Nassau County pays $4.27 million for eight-acre Meyers farm property in Woodbury as part of campaign to save county's remaining parcels of open space; photo (S)

block.p: No luxury homes or condos will be built on the Meyers farm property in Woodbury, one of the five remaining working farms in Nassau County.

On Tuesday, Thomas R. Suozzi, the county executive, said that as part of a campaign to save Nassau's remaining parcels of open space, the county had bought the development rights for the eight-acre farm at the intersection of Picquets Lane and Woodbury Road for $4.27 million.
No luxury homes or condos will be built on the Meyers farm property in Woodbury, one of the five remaining working farms in Nassau County.

On Tuesday, Thomas R. Suozzi, the county executive, said that as part of a campaign to save Nassau's remaining parcels of open space, the county had bought the development rights for the eight-acre farm at the intersection of Picquets Lane and Woodbury Road for $4.27 million.
The Meyers family, which has owned the farm since 1920, will continue farming the land, where they grow vegetables and flowers that are sold at their farm stand.
Mr. Suozzi said he hoped to buy the development rights to other farms.
''There's a lot of pressure on farmers to sell to developers,'' he said. ''We are trying to take the pressure off for them so that they can still farm on their land.''
